summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney, dated March 23, 2008, expressing concern about Jeffrey Epstein's investigators allegedly harassing victims and their parents. The email describes an incident where an investigator threatened a victim with releasing a supposed video of her on the internet. It also notes Epstein is using the state criminal case to subpoena depositions of victims in the federal case to gather information about the federal investigation, and asks for intervention to stop these aggressive tactics.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; his investigators are allegedly harassing victims and their parents, and he is using legal tactics to subpoena victim depositions.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Author of the email, reporting on aggressive investigator activity against victims and seeking intervention to stop it.

connections.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney is involved in the federal investigation against Epstein and is reporting on his team's alleged misconduct.

events.title: Investigator threatens victim with video
events.description: An investigator working for Epstein allegedly demanded to see a victim, told her they had video of her, and threatened to put it on the internet, causing a frantic call from the victim's parents.

events.title: Email sent regarding investigator harassment
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney sends an email reporting on Epstein's investigators harassing victims and their parents, and asks for intervention to stop these actions.

keyFacts: Epstein's investigators allegedly harassed victims and their parents, with one incident involving a threat to release a supposed video of a victim on the internet.
Epstein was using the state criminal case to subpoena depositions of victims in the federal case to gather information about the federal investigation.

The Assistant U.S. Attorney viewed these actions as inconsistent with what Epstein's attorneys were supposedly trying to work out in Washington, D.C., and requested intervention to 'call off their dogs'.
